image.altText: An illustration of the outlines of four women, the background behind is purple.

props.synopsis: Since 2000, 81 women have been killed by their partners in the Northern Territory. Four of them have been at the centre of a landmark coronial inquiry. The evidence has been devastating and repetitive — but will it spark change?

title.children: As domestic violence services cry out for funding, the NT government builds two new art galleries

props.synopsis: A group of tourists say they'll never return to Alice Springs after a trip to Uluru ended in a brawl between their driver and a pedestrian, and an hours-long wait on the side of the road.

title.children: 'I was just waiting for the bus to crash': Tourists left shaken by dramatic trip to Uluru

image.altText: large cloud of black smoke rises into a blue sky  above an urban area

props.synopsis: In his strongest comments to date on civilians bearing the brunt of the war, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken denounces the soaring number of civilians killed in Gaza.

title.children: Blinken says 'far too many' Palestinians killed, Hamas says Israeli strikes hit hospitals

image.altText: a woman and a man in a bowtie stand outside a building with a logo reading Commonwealth Bank

props.synopsis: The inside story of how the Commonwealth Bank went to extraordinary lengths to discredit whistleblowers and journalists who exposed wrongdoing within the company.

title.children: 'Not dead enough': When a man had a heart attack, the Commonwealth Bank told politicians he was a fraudster

image.altText: A tight shot of Jim Chalmers head, he wears a suit and red tie stands in front of a blue curtain

props.synopsis: The growing sullenness amongst voters about cost of living pressures makes it inevitable that the economy will once again become the absolute core issue for the government, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Australia's economy is morphing before our eyes – and lots of 'small bang' decisions are required

image.altText: A woman wearing a corchet top on the beach.

props.synopsis: On the holiday island of Phuket, an influx of Russians buying property and setting up their own businesses is driving up prices and driving a wedge between the new residents and Thai locals.

title.children: Step inside the luxurious new playground for rich Russians fleeing Vladimir Putin's war

image.altText: A large crowd of people walking towards the camera.

props.synopsis: The US has struggled to maintain support for Israel's offensive in the face of the shocking civilian death toll in Gaza. It is now taking a new line, writes Eric Tlozek.

title.children: Cracks appear between Israel and the US over a 'pause' in the campaign in Gaza

image.altText: A hand places their smart phone near a sleek Eftpos machine on the wooden counter of a cafe.

props.synopsis: Businesses were hit hard during the Optus outage, with EFTPOS machines left out of action. As Australia moves further towards being completely cashless, experts say the outage isn't enough to see cash return as king.

title.children: The Optus outage has thrown our cashless society into question, but experts say there's no going back

image.altText: A group of people dressed in Navy uniforms stand on a submarine.

props.synopsis: A senior Pentagon official insists "little bumps" inside congress will not delay progress on the plan to provide Australia with nuclear-powered submarines.

title.children: Top Pentagon official assures Australian on AUKUS submarines deal despite congressional difficulties

image.altText: Students during an examination.

props.synopsis: Students and parents are calling for more transparency and adequate solutions from the VCE authority after at least two high schools gave Chinese language students the wrong exam paper this week.

title.children: Students and parents demand answers after at least two high schools hand out wrong paper in VCE Chinese exam

image.altText: Glass of almost empty beer on a wooden table at night in a beer garden

props.synopsis: Australia has seen a rise in "zero-alcohol" beverages on the market. But some still contain low levels of alcohol, leading to potential confusion for customers, especially those who are pregnant or breastfeeding.

title.children: Can you have 'non-alcoholic' drinks while pregnant? Health experts say one thing, brewers say another

image.altText: Generic image of a Sri Lanka cricketer at the men's World Cup

props.synopsis: The International Cricket Council determines that Sri Lanka Cricket is in serious breach of its obligations as a member, issuing a suspension with immediate effect.

title.children: ICC suspends Sri Lanka's membership over government interference

image.altText: Shiny coils and pipes form part of a super cold quantum refrigerator.

props.synopsis: The Stawell Underground Physics Laboratory is about to become home to a "quantum refrigerator", in a first for physicists in the Southern Hemisphere.

title.children: Why a fridge '300 times colder than space' is headed for an underground lab regional Victoria

image.altText: A magazine cover with an image of  bright orange motorcycle and orange print

props.synopsis: Among the long rows of glossy publications that cater to the reading needs of home renovators, gold hunters, hobby farmers, celebrity watchers, and puzzle lovers, this newsagent is witnessing a resurgence in demand for print magazines.

title.children: Glossy mags are making a comeback thanks to 'lipstick effect'

image.altText: A shot of an artifical reef underwater

props.synopsis: Residents along Victoria's coast are fighting back against coastal erosion with innovative and environmentally friendly solutions.

title.children: As the tide ebbs on this Victorian coast, a curious line of domes come into view

image.altText: A large yellow sea snake in an aquarium tank

props.synopsis: Come along on a trip to Exmouth Gulf as researchers hunt for one of the ocean's most cryptic creatures.

title.children: Unravelling the mysteries of sea snakes in Exmouth Gulf with a net and spotlight

image.altText: A for sale sign in front of a rundown house

props.synopsis: With the surging costs of homes in Australia, more young people are relying on family to enter the market. It has experts concerned about deepening class disparity.

title.children: In a housing crisis, the bank of mum and dad can help. But is it a good idea?

image.altText: A photo of a young boy in a broken frame, draped in a Western Bulldogs scarf

props.synopsis: The Western Bulldogs sexual abuse scandal could widen, after survivor Adam Kneale was awarded the highest compensation payout in history.

title.children: The Western Bulldogs were hit with an 'earthquake' legal judgement. The aftershocks could follow

image.altText: Vidya Rajan wearing a yellow saree, with her parents, all holding sparklers and celebrating Diwali in Western Australia.

props.synopsis: I think it's important to continue smaller gatherings to mark cultural events — it's how we build community, after all.

title.children: This year for Diwali, I’m starting a new tradition — a potluck dinner for my found family

image.altText: Two women and a man dressed in traditional Samoan attire

props.synopsis: Pasifika people are generous people – their commitment to serving and supporting others is central to their identities. But that generosity comes at a cost.

title.children: How 'a manifestation of love' can become a financial burden in Samoan communities

image.altText: a woman with cropped hair wearing a white collared shirt

props.synopsis: A high-ranking Northern Territory police officer — who was off duty and wearing plain clothes at the time — has refuted allegations she assaulted a woman during an arrest on an outback highway.

title.children: NT police officer denies assault allegations over off-duty roadside arrest

image.altText: A blonde woman holding her hat shakes the hand of an older man with white hair. Behind them are many other people.

props.synopsis: After eight weeks of evidence, across the past six months, Northern Territory Coroner Elisabeth Armitage has adjourned her landmark inquiry into the NT's domestic, family and sexual violence system.

title.children: 'Her life still matters': NT domestic violence inquiry wraps up after six months

image.altText: NT Chief Minister Natasha Fyles standing and speaking at a lectern, in front of several flags.

props.synopsis: In a submission to an inquiry into the Middle Arm Development Precinct, the NT government has listed Closing the Gap as a key "strategic" reason to pursue the $1.5 billion project.

title.children: NT government says controversial project involving gas plant will help close the gap for Indigenous Territorians

image.altText: An Australian player bowls spin at the men's Cricket World Cup.

props.synopsis: With the Cricket World Cup semifinals on the horizon, Australia is looking to capitalise on Glenn Maxwell's all-round ability, rather than just his powerful batting.

title.children: How Australia plans to use Maxwell for more than his batting prowess in its World Cup campaign

image.altText: Sally, left, smiles as she prepares clay in her hands on a table, next to Eden, who laughs as she looks down doing the same.

props.synopsis: Old People's Home for Teenagers brings 91-year-old Sally and 19-year-old Eden together to make pinch pots — helping to ensure this important practice and its lessons don't end when the clay of the master sets in the kiln.

title.children: 'Growing old allows me to be more confident' says 91-year-old ceramicist Sally as she passes on the art

image.altText: A tiger snake in a green hedge.

props.synopsis: Fiona Tustian enjoys having snakes in her garden, but they're not everyone's cup of tea. So how can you reduce the chances of one taking up residence in your yard?

title.children: Warning as snakes appear from above hunting birds in trees

image.altText: woman lying in the back seat of a car

props.synopsis: After escaping a turbulent home life, she found herself homeless at least three times before she even turned 18.

title.children: Summer used to sleep in a car with a knife under her pillow. She considered herself one of the 'privileged' ones

image.altText: A young cowgirl wearing jeans, hat and a pink shirt riding her horse.

props.synopsis: Karen Webb considers herself an outback Uber driver. But that's life on the rodeo circuit for the proud country mum and her daughter, riding sensation Adanni Walker.

title.children: Cowgirl rides 'outback Uber' all the way to rodeo's bright lights

image.altText: Ebony Marinoff pumps her fists while celebrating a win with the crowd

props.synopsis: With the top eight settled and AFLW finals on the horizon, Gemma Bastiani takes a look at the greatest strength of each remaining team.

title.children: Each of the AFLW top eight's biggest assets ahead of finals

image.altText: A dark, moody photo of a woman wearing a green sweater laying on her back, reading a book

props.synopsis: Anna Funder's new book excoriates a truth unchanged from both before and after George Orwell's time: What women do in a marriage, in a family, creates more time for the other members of that family than they would ever have without her, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: The Australian book dropping truth bombs and leaving women furious

image.altText: Perth Glory A-League Women player Jessika Cowart prepares to kick the ball during a game.

props.synopsis: After making history in their first appearance at the FIFA Women's World Cup, players from the Philippines national team are now experiencing Australia’s passion for women's football.

title.children: Filipinas ride on Women's World Cup fever by playing in the A-League Women

image.altText: A young woman with shaved brown hair wearing a bright pink vest sitting on a bench inside South Australia's Parliament House.

props.synopsis: Australia still lags behind dozens of countries when it comes to female representation in federal parliament. A national program is now equipping more women with the skills and confidence to run for office.

title.children: When it comes to women in parliament, Australia lags behind — but this program hopes to change that

image.altText: An island with white sandy beaches, turquoise water, swaying palms and blue sky.

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a new pact with the low-lying island country of Tuvalu, allowing residents facing displacement from climate change the ability to resettle in Australia.

title.children: Tuvalu residents able to resettle in Australia as climate change 'threatens its existence'

image.altText: A storm picture shows hail falling on a residential street in Lockyer Valley

props.synopsis: A 70-year-old woman has died after being crushed by a falling tree during a storm in the Lockyer Valley.

title.children: Woman dies after being crushed by falling tree during wild storms

image.altText: Police arrest a man

props.synopsis: Drink bottles and racial slurs were thrown from both sides at each other, while one man was arrested in an angry protest in Caulfield South.

title.children: Pro-Palestinian and pro-Israel protestors clash in Melbourne's inner south-east
